INSTRUMENT: DAEDALUS SPECTROMETER HOST: FIELD EXPERIMENT
Instrument Information ====================== Instrument Id : DAED Instrument Host Id : FEXP Instrument Name : DAEDALUS SPECTROMETER Instrument Type : SPECTROMETER Instrument Manufacturer Name : DAEDALUS ENTERPRISES, INC.
Instrument Description ====================== The Daedalus AA440 Spectrafax instrument is a hand-held portable field spectrometer. The Daedalus measures radiance between the wavelengths of 0.45 and 2.4 micrometers in 288 channels. Wavelength resolution varies from 0.01 micrometers in the visible to 0.04 micrometers in the infrared. The angular field of view is 1.5 degrees, which means the field of view is about 2.5 cm when the instrument height is about 1 meter. Detectors are a silicon detector for wavelengths between 0.4 and 1.1 micrometers and a lead sulfide detector for wavelengths between 1.1 and 2.4 micrometers.
The instrument has a circular filter wheel with 360 optical interference filters in three overlapping wavelength segments. Overlapping segments must be edited to properly display a Daedalus spectrum. Measured radiance values are digitized to values in the range of 0 to 1023 (10 bits). The instrument has a variable gain setting to adjust the dynamic range. The gain scale is logarithmic in which one step represents about a 16 percent change in gain. A change in gain of 4 units is approximately a factor of 2 change in the digitized output signal.
Reflectance values are derived by ratioing the signal of a sample to that of a pressed and bonded halon standard viewed at the same lighting angle. Note that a difference in gain setting for the standard and the target must be accounted for when computing reflectance. The derived reflectance values are radiance coefficients.
Science Objectives ================== Make spectral reflectance measurements of field and laboratory samples.
Operational Considerations ========================== If the Daedalus instrument is hand-held with the instrument height only approximately fixed, there can be a small difference in the height used to measure the calibration standard and a given sample. Such a height difference will produce a systematic error in the absolute reflectance value. Each centimeter difference in height will produce about a 2% change in reflectance.
Calibration Description ======================= Calibration is done by measuring a pressed and bonded halon standard with the same lighting and viewing geometry as the surface sample.
